reviewText: They don't give a crap about the English only speaking players, they only use us as cannon fodder to the Veteran Russian players that transfered over from the UE server that they shutdown because of all the cheating they let go on. All the Russian players that transfered over to the steam server where all above level 25 and most of them were already maxed put at level 30. They got to bring 2 level 5 weapons that will kill the lower level stalkers with 1 or 2 shots and they were allowed to bring 1 set of level 5 armor which level 4 weapons and below hardly do any damage to them at all. Also its almost impossible for new players ever to get level 5 weapons as they know where the artifacts spawn that are needed to make them and they camp those area's amd KOS all english players.\n\nThey continued to scam devs" the EU server English only players by giving the "updates" in Russian only

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ENGLISH REVIEW

Years ago work began on the MMORPS “Stalker-Online”, which – heavily inspired by the world created in GSC Game World’s cult classic “S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl” – sought to recreate that world in a multiplayer environment. For reasons unknown to me, a dispute broke out between two groups in the studio which worked on Stalker-Online. It was divided into two teams and both of them retained the rights for the project, but only one holds ownership of its name. Hence we now have two productions: Stalker-Online and “sZone-Online”, which are almost identical and to this day remain very similar to the closed beta of the first project from 2010.

Their graphics resemble an early alpha version of Shadow of Chernobyl, which by today’s standards is even more dated and stings the eyes with its ugliness. Nevertheless, the Eastern European style is accurately portrayed through the abandoned housing estates and other such Chernobylesque locations in-game, which should please fans of the original Stalker, though some more music and sounds would be nice. Unfortunately the performance of sZone-Online is awful even on good computers – with a GTX 770, an i5-3350P and 8 GB of RAM, the frame rate on my PC was swinging from 20 to 80 frames per second in the most random of situations, which sometimes caused slight nausea and hampered fighting. There are also crashes and lag, even when you have a good connection.

The gameplay is painful. Combat is exceptionally unfair and unrealistically designed; using firearms feels unsatisfying, enemies function like so-called “mobs” from ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes (meaning they can sometimes notice you out of nowhere and attack you in swarms), and when you die you must wait 30 seconds before your character can get up again – of course with a minimal amount of health points – in the same dangerous area… The waiting time increases with each death. Alternatively you can respawn at the nearest stalker base (and the maps are large), but by choosing this option you risk losing precious items from your inventory.

Normally I don’t complain about rare ammo in games (quite the opposite), but in sZone – where it’s possible to die so easily, in such unforeseen circumstances and lose so much – it really is irritating. This is not S.T.A.L.K.E.R. or Metro 2033, where you can triumph over numerous enemies without wasting mass quantities of ammunition thanks to your own skill. In sZone-Online your character moves like a tank with the durability of a piece of toilet paper and all your efforts are liable to incongruous MMORPG gameplay elements, many bugs and the aforementioned terrible frame rate. Improving character skills and acquiring useful gear also takes an annoying amount of time.

However, when you do find yourself alone after nightfall in the wilderness, far from any NPC camps and hours past the starting areas of the game… then you’ll start to feel that atmosphere. You feel vulnerable and endangered. When interaction between players comes into play, who may be stalkers in a similar situation and become your comrades or turn out to be simple bandits, sZone becomes much more interesting.

In conclusion: sZone draws too much from traditional MMORPGs – boring quests, no engaging story, microtransactions and gameplay that rewards “grinding” as opposed to skill (which is at odds with the first-person shooter combat model). Furthermore, the game is barely evolving and has very shady roots… This whole project is based on plagiarism. Cybertime System is not the first developer to try to capitalise on fans of GSC Game World’s works. Even though in sZone you can experience a few amazing moments, overall it is a badly created game that will never reach its potential due to deep contradictions in its design.

---

POLSKA RECENZJA

Lata temu zaczęto pracę nad MMORPS „Stalker-Online”, która – mocno zainspirowana światem stworzonym przez GSC Game World w kultowej grze „S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Cień Czarnobyla” – miała na celu odtworzenie tegoż świata w trybie wieloosobowym. Z niewiadomych mi powodów doszło do sporu między dwoma grupami w studiu, które zajmowało się tworzeniem Stalker-Online. Podzieliło się ono na dwa zespoły i oba z nich zatrzymały prawo do projektu, ale tylko jeden do jego nazwy. W taki sposób mamy teraz dwie produkcje: Stalker-Online i „sZone-Online”, które do dziś są niemalże identyczne i wciąż bardzo podobne do zamkniętej bety pierwszego projektu z 2010 roku.

Grafika przypomina wczesną wersję alfa Cienia Czarnobyla, co na dzisiejsze standardy jest jeszcze bardziej przestarzałe i kłuje w oczy brzydotą. Niemniej jednak, ten wschodnioeuropejski styl jest trafnie odzwierciedlony przez opuszczone blokowiska i inne czarnobylskie lokacje w grze, co powinno spodobać się fanom oryginalnego Stalkera, chociaż przydałoby się trochę więcej muzyki i dźwięków. Niestety wydajność sZone-Online jest okropna nawet na dobrych komputerach – z GTX 770, i5-3350P i 8 GB RAMu, częstotliwość klatek huśtała się na moim pececie od 20 do 80 klatek na sekundę i to w kompletnie losowych sytuacjach, co momentami powodowało lekkie mdłości i mocno utrudniało bój. Są także krasze i lagi nawet, gdy ma się dobre połączenie.

Rozgrywka jest bolesna. Walka jest niezwykle podła i nierealistycznie zaprojektowana; strzelanie z broni palnej czuje się niesatysfakcjonujące, wrogowie funkcjonują jak tzw. „moby” z gier MMO (czyli czasem potrafią ciebie dostrzec znikąd i rzucić się na ciebie całym mrowiem), a gdy zginiesz musisz czekać 30 sekund zanim twoja postać będzie mogła znów wstać – oczywiście z minimalną ilością punktów życia – w tym samym niebezpiecznym miejscu… Czas czekania powiększa się z każdą śmiercią. Alternatywnie możesz odrodzić się od razu w najbliższej bazie stalkerów (a mapy są wielkie), ale wybierając tę opcję ryzykujesz utratę cennych przedmiotów ze swojego ekwipunku.

Normalnie nie narzekam na rzadkość amunicji w grach (wręcz przeciwnie), lecz w sZone – gdzie można zginąć tak łatwo, w tak nieoczekiwanych okolicznościach i stracić tak wiele – jest to naprawdę irytujące. To nie S.T.A.L.K.E.R. czy Metro 2033, gdzie można zwyciężyć z licznymi wrogami bez marnowania masowych ilości amunicji dzięki własnym umiejętnościom. W sZone-Online twoja postać porusza się jak czołg z wytrzymałością kawałka papieru toaletowego a wszystkie twoje starania podlegają niepasującym elementom rozgrywki MMORPG, liczebnym błędom gry i wcześniej wspomnianej marnej wydajności. Polepszanie umiejętności postaci i zdobywanie przydatnego sprzętu także zajmuje denerwująco dużo czasu.

Natomiast, gdy już znajdziesz się sam w dziczy po zmroku, daleko od najbliższego obozu NPCów i już kilka godzin po zwiedzeniu początkowych miejsc w grze… wtedy naprawdę zaczniesz czuć ten klimat. Czujesz się wrażliwy i zagrożony. Gdy w grę wchodzi interakcja między graczami, którzy mogą być stalkerami w podobnej sytuacji i stać się twoimi towarzyszami lub okazać się zwykłymi bandytami, sZone staje się dużo bardziej interesujące.

Podsumowując: sZone za dużo czerpie z tradycyjnych MMORPGów – m.in. nudne zadania, brak wciągającej fabuły, mikropłatności i rozgrywkę, która nagradza za „grinding” a nie zręczność (co jest sprzeczne z modelem walki strzelanki pierwszoosobowej). Co więcej, gra prawie wcale się nie rozwija i ma bardzo podejrzane korzenie… Cały ten projekt jest oparty na plagiacie. Cybertime Studios to nie jedyny producent, który próbuje skapitalizować niedosyt fanów twórczości GSC Game World. Mimo że w sZone-Online można doświadczyć kilka niesamowitych chwil, ogólnie jest to źle stworzona gra, która nigdy nie osiągnie swojego potencjału ze względu na głębokie sprzeczności w tym, jak jest zaprojektowana.

Hi. First of all, I'm russian and I know this game for years, so let me bring some vital information for you, because you probably don't know anything about this masterpiece" =)

This game is a clone of original Stalker-Online project (it still exists and is much better that this one). This game was stolen by some developers and they decided to publish it asap to gain as much money as they can. But let me show you main problems:

* Ugly FPS: 10-15 instead of 30-60 (in original Stalker Online).
* Graphics (it's ugly here)
* Server lags (I have 500ms ping on 160Mbps optical internet channel in Russia!!!)
* "Waiting for authorization
date:
please wait" is the only thing you will see for hours...
* MoneyMaking. It means you are nothing without real money in this game. The only thing devs want is to take your money.
* Ugly support: be ready to wait for days for answers on your claims...

And much more... Don't be silly

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of the bad reviews seem to be coming from people so staggeringly stupid that they don't bother to read what anyone says, or try anything ingame before they give up. That is fine, they wouldn't last long anyway. The game itself is actully pretty good when it works. It is unforgiving when it comes to dying, there is a MASSIVE amount of land to explore across several maps, and the gameplay is alright as long as you aren't dropping to 5 fps because of the memory leak. They managed to mostly capture the atmosphere of the STALKER games, but not 100%. My biggest complaint has to be with their moderators though, they seem to be completely inept and unable to even work on their own account system.
tl:dr- The game is fine if you can deal with slow progression, but god help you if you have to submit a support ticket, they don't even speak English.

-Edit
Bar none the worst game support I have ever tried to use. Hours in between responses, no English, and they are content to let your ticket go unresolved. I just closed a ticket after over seven days with no progress towards fixing my issue.

reviewText:
Being a huge stalker fan I really tried to give this game a chance. I invested 20+hrs to dig a little deeper than most of the reviews of ppl with less than 1h playtime. Unfortunately it was a waste of time and I came to pretty much the same conclusions.

It's a real shame as in theory there's everything in place to make a great game (crafting, skills, barter, professions and different classes, lots of quest and huge map to explore, pve & pvp etc..) but the overall execution is utter ♥♥♥♥.

Devs are working on a v2 on the unreal engine (beta opens in february). It basically means that despite what they say this game is officialy dead and there's no improvments in sight. Huge potential, terrible disappointment.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of Stalker series, I was really excited when I saw this project on Steam. Jumped into it and immediately felt that warm welcome of the Stalker appeal. The atmosphere is very immersive, and the dialogue (russian) has that unique sarcastic Stalker appeal with humorous twists. The shooting works and once you put a scope on your AK gets actually pretty fun. It is also super satisfying to finally find an artifact and sell it for large profits, especially since the zone makes you feel really vulnerable, with potential danger lurking around any corner.

Now for the negatives: This game is utter ♥♥♥♥. It is poorly optimized, supper buggy and will literally lag every minute no matter of your system. Somehow I was able to overlook it for 25 hours even though there is a bug around every corner. Theoretically everything is there to make a great game: quests, interesting NPCs, tons of guns, PVP, crafting and levelling system.

Only THEY ♥♥♥♥ED UP THE LEVELLING SYSTEM. Once you gain the first easy couple of levels you realize a massive downside. To gain any perks that will actually help you with your chosen specialization (reduced gun wear, increased aiming, animal part gathering, etc), you basically need to put in an unrealistic amount of grinding work. For example to gain the 1st level perk for assault rifles as a warrior you must get 300 specialized points. 1 point = 46000xp. One quests gives you 300-500xp and killing mobs is under 100xp. Some quests do give a few thousands, but you'll run out of them long before you get a  1'000'000 experience points. Honestly, if you somehow have half a life time to put into levelling of this game just to get a SINGLE 1st LVL PERK, then I hope your grandkids can enjoy your work. After registering on the Russian forums, I found out this was already the formula in 2013, so I dont know what paint the devs have been sniffing for the last 2 years but they completely ruined the game. Oh and to top it all off, you can use real money to purchase in game items, but they have a limited amount of time for usage. Who does that, especically on a broken game. All in all ♥♥♥♥ this game and ♥♥♥♥ the devs for slapping the title Stalker on a piece of turd.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is exactly how an online STALKER game should be. It needs work, but it nails the atmosphere and style which is unique to that universe.

Your character is of no significance at all.  No world saving or god-slaying heroes here, just you and your crappy AK against hordes of mutants, deadly environmental anomalies, and fellow scavengers.  I'll run through what's good, what's bad, and what could be improved.

The Good:

-Atmosphere:  Mostly cloudy days running through abandoned towns, old factories and railway stations, with not much more than the sounds of nature to accompany you is in line with how STALKER is supposed to be.

-PvP + PvE:  There aren't strict divisions between PvP and PvE;  rather, you can opt to turn on PvP at any time using an icon in the upper left, which will change the color of your name and render you vulnerable to other players' weapons.  PvP is automatically turned on, however, if the total worth of your inventory/gear exceeds a certain threshold, which I think is a great way to put you in the mindset of a scavenger among other scavengers - you don't want to have your most valuable stuff with you for too long and around too many people, lest they try to take it from you.  Killing other players within sight of town guards/NPC's will net you a negative reputation temporarily, meaning players who get too trigger happy find themselves losing out on certain conveniences for a time.  There's also a PvP arena with different modes similar to the multiplayer in the actual STALKER games, with rewards even for when you lose.

-Quests:  There are an ungodly number of quests, and while they can be difficult, I've yet to run into more than one or two which explicitly required a team of people.  Rewards are usually shown before the quest is completed, meaning you can make more effective decisions about how to use your time, and you rarely get surprised with a bad reward for a hard quest.  Some involve a LOT of traveling, though, which can wear on you a bit.

-Maps:  They're gigantic.  Lots of places to explore, with randomly-generated, respawning loot, as well as valuable artifacts if you choose to investigate anomalies.  It is not hard to make a lot of money outside of questing, if you learn where to look.

-The Community:  It's weird to say this is good when the dominant quality of the community is indifference.  People don't seem to communicate much, and when they do it's usually very short and to the point, but it's so fitting with how STALKER works that I see it as a plus for the game.  You'll get used to aiming first and asking questions second, as you never know who might decide to pull the trigger and rob you.  And  yes, you can get robbed.  That said, helping people goes a long way, and you build trust more by actually doing something rather than talking to someone.


The Bad

-Sounds:  Sound quality is fairly basic, and some of it doesn't work consistently.  Music plays in some locations but is apparently so specific to a location that it just cuts out when you move.  Monsters make noise, but you can only really hear them when they're on you, meaning you could have a small horde of them chasing you and not actually know it until you've been gored and left for dead.  It's highly annoying sometimes when you're exploring only to be killed without so much as the sound of a footstep for warning.

-Aggro distance:  Sometimes a monster sees you and comes after you in a way which totally makes sense.  Sometimes they show up almost out of nowhere and kill you in one hit.  Sometimes they kill you, leave, and when you respawn show up from some crazy distance away to gnaw on you again.  Combine that with the lack of audio indicating their presence, and you'll feel like you're getting cheap-shotted a LOT.  Verliokas" are especially terrible about this - they make no noise
recommended: and will aggro from insane distances in places where you can't see anything.\n\n-Graphics:  The graphics are dated and have some issues here and there.  Textures flicker

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a huge SCAM.  It's actually a F2P game with microtransations.  But nowhere on the Steam page does it say that it's F2P.  In fact, they put down that they may be raising the price to try to get people to buy it up now.  You can download and play it for free right off their website here (http://szone-online.net/)

If you paid for this game, you should ask for a refund in Steam Customer Support and tell them about this.

Edit: Specifically, it's about putting it up as a paid game to try to circumvent steam F2P microtransaction fees on the devs - so that Valve doesn't get their cut.  For the people who have the game: When you try to make a microtransaction purchase in-game, does it take you to the steam page?  It doesn't.  I hope Valve catches on to this soon.

Edit:  Refunded 1-1-15 7:09PM (Central Time).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty cool. I'll start with cons, then pros. It'll be a simple review.

Cons:
- Bad graphics
- Bad performance
- Not fully translated yet, but a dev told me the full translation (except for the newest quests) is coming march.
- Sometimes a bit confusing
- For some this is a con, but there is NO hand holding. This is the reason of the above mentioned con
- Weapons are given extremely quickly. In the first area, after like 1 quest and talking to 1 dude (and having to do nothing) you can have a shotgun and AK.

Pros:
- Interesting theme and atmosphere
- Skill tree, professions and crafting
- Loads of quests, with no quest markers. You have to figure it out with the information provided in your Journal and from the quest-giver. The fact that the game isn't fully translated yet makes this VERY hard.
- Open-world, pretty game. Not pretty because of graphics, but because of the theme and scenery.

I recommend this game, even there are more cons than pros. Just play it for yourself, it's free.

reviewText:
sZone Online is a bit like a mix between DayZ, STALKER, and an MMORPG. It's environment mimicks that of the STALKER franchise. The gameplay is a bit similar to DayZ (though not exactly), and it has some heavy MMORPG aspects.

Many of the poor" reviews I'm seeing on here are from a lack of understanding of the game.

First: Tips for newbies

1. Talk to Sour and Blacksmith. They will give you free weapons and some rewarding quests

2. Push N to hide other players

3. Push F to talk to NPCs. Translations have improved immensely. Be sure to read the quest dialogue. Often it gives you more info on what needs to be done then the journal

4. The area you first come to is the tutorial city.

5. The FPS has improved but large populations may change it

6. We have three servers. EU PvP
recommended: and US PvP. Their locations are obvious and each will determine your ping and what the majority of players speak in terms of language\n\n7. When I played a lot about a year-year and a half ago
hoursPlayed: there was open world PvP. This caused a lot of problems. People would shut down entire towns with snipers and such
voteText: mass DM. As a result
helpfulPercent:
it appears they've changed it. I will update this mroe as I learn the new system. There is also clan wars PvP and Arena PvP.

8. Clans can go to war with one another and capture territories on the second map you visit.

9. Yes there are anomalies and artifacts.

10. The game can be very difficult. Take your time. The key skills to doing well in this game is taking things slow
votesHelpful: planning
votesTotal: accuracy
votesFunny: and socializing.\n\n11. Push I to open inventory
commentsCount: U to open character
column16: K to see your skills
column17: and J to see your current quests\n\n12. There are still some things in Russian. It has improved immensely
column18:
but it isn't uncommon to see something you don't understand.

13. To get out of the starter city the NPC named Duchonik (if that's how you spell) at the Police Station near the kindergarden gate will start a quest chain. Leaving via this way will side you with the military and their allies in terms of reputation you get. The reputation effects is minimal so you don't have to worry about this too much. The other way is to talk to Courier and do his chain at the north settlement in the city. This one sides more with the STALKERs/underground.

Overall I give the game a 8/10. They fixed a lot of issues with the pings

reviewText:
Short: too many bugs, too many time-consuming / fun-killing 'features'
After 80 hours (and reaching level 10 with a native pathfinder) I am not pleased with my gaming experience.

Long:
+Stalker scenario
+huge 'open' world
+(in theory) good crafting system
+PVP and PVE servers

-fences block your movement and force you in certain directions
-involves a lot of running around in an empty world
-guide system for quick travel is not very logical (travel from A to B, but at B, you can only travel back to A) and sometimes requires rare / expensive fuel
-items needed for crafting are rare / only  available via daily missions / not found at all
-crafting might fail and you loose all items involved, or you get garbage, tools are consumed anyway
-bugs / hackers can kill you in PVE server in secure zones while still flagged as 'newbie'
-lots of xp needed for raising skills / abilities
-time-consuming quests with ridiculous rewards, farming is often quicker (and boring)
-high-level mutants (bear) drop cheap loot
-mobs sometimes spawn right around / behind you
-when killed by anomalies / spawning mobs you cannot escape, and have to respawn
-when respawning, you might loose some items / weapons / equipment
-anomalies often kill you without warning (ok, throw rocks all the time, while running all the time, time-consuming)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very slow moving game, but nice graphics.  Once you get out of the first map it's more interesting.

Unfortunately the developers are not responsive and have a tendency to ban people from the discussion forums and the game for pointing out the serious issues they refuse to address, which are :

The chat moderators are people that play the game and constantly provoke people.  This is considered extremely unprofessional anywhere else but in this game.  The chat moderators will harass people until they say something that is considered a chat bannable offense.  Complaints about this kind of set up they entirely ignore.

The rampant, obvious, cheating.  It's very clear that people cheat in this game and the developers not only allow it, they encourage it.  They actually told some of the most obvious cheaters that they had turned off the anti-cheat system.  Which brings me to the big final huge minus about this game.

The developers constantly lie.  They claimed that the anti-cheat system had been running all along, then admitted later that they had turned it off, yet told some of the worst offenders it was turned off, encouraging them to cheat.  The developers also banned people who did not cheat for several days, and accused people who had not cheated of cheating, and refused to apologize or compensate them in any way.

Overall this is the most negative gaming experience I have ever had.  I do not recommend sZone, primarily because they defraud the players by implying you have any chance of fair PVP play, if you would just BUY some better gear.  Then you buy that gear and discover rapidly that it doesn't matter; the developers have people playing the game that they know cheat for the expressed purpose of conning you into spending money on something that is of almost no use.

Read through the complaints and look at the hours people have put into this game.  Any other serious game developer really cares about the people who are playing the game the most, they actually value their input.  sZone does not.

reviewText:
I loaded the game up and was greeted with a screen of my character which had no body. Alright fair enough, the game has some bugs on release. So I logged in, the game has some weird camera feel to it, it's like my FoV is 50 and there's headbob when you sit still. The game runs... okay I guess for what it looks like and being a mmo. I started a quest, got a gun, and had some of the most awkward feeling gun combat ever. I've played f2p CS knock offs that felt more natural. No iron sights, gun accuracy is random, and for some reason you have a loading bar pop up for every interaction. Want to switch guns? Here's a loading bar even though you already have the other gun out.

I started pelting homeless npcs with rocks, until another player came by and we had a rock fight. Which was interrupted by some random dude clipping through the ground with only his neck and head visible. I then wandered for a bit, found some NPC guards who walked like they ♥♥♥♥ themselves all the way down to the legs. I then decided I had had enough.

RIP STALKER

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHave been playing ths game for a bit now and am really enjoying the gameplay and missions. This game will feel very confusing and a bit overpowering with you being thrown into the world at the start, but as you continue it all starts to come together and become addicting. Also the missions can be very vauge, such as just asking to find a person with not indication of where to look which may prove annoying. It has alot of end game material/unlocks that seem impossible but are for people who have played for a LONG, LONG time. I recommend this game if you enjoy a fairly hard game, for people who wan't a game where they can become op in a matter of a few hours will not find this game fun. I feel the pro's overpower the flaw's in the game at this point in time. I Hope this reiview proves helpful in one way or another!!!

reviewText:
Its pretty awful. Kinda feels like a very very very VERY early product rather than something thats been out for years now.

Pay no attention to the hours i've spent on it - i'm just weird like that.

*Edit* alright its been mentioned that I should probably clarify that - I insanely like survival/apocalyptic games and any game that lets me hide in some bushes spying on some noobs before rushing out - screaming and spraying a machine gun for no reason other than ♥♥♥♥♥ 'n giggles is worth at least some of my time. But the game handles it rather terribly with unpolished gameplay, bugs up the goddam ♥♥♥, and a world that feels empty and devoid of life (although that might be something of the point - however if you need to sacrifice gameplay for story you should always head back to the drawing board to see where things went wrong IMO).

Maybe I can recomend it to anyone looking for a real hardcore MMO type deal since pretty much all enemies can quickly kill you if you arn't paying attention, PVP is allowed in all places except select safezones, invisible anomalies can insta-kill you, and (for the most part) the game leaves you to figure out things for yourself.

However there is a vast difference between a simulation and a video game for me and I vastly prefer the second, but this feels more like the first. Forgive me for becoming complacent but I would like to know why the guy I need to talk to for my quest is simply telling me to sod off rather than what I need to do to win his favour and instead I just wander off - mindlessly completing quests and killing monsters in the area hoping he eventually notices me like a disaproving father.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game as an MMORPG is not at all bad,but the main problem would be is how newbies don't get much support. Usually we would have clans recruiting newbies to help them progress better in the game,by giving them advice,giving them free items and money,when there was absolutely no English Translation,and I'm talking about the non-steam versions of this,where all of it was just Russian. The gameplay demands tolerance and patience,as there are bugs,occasinal lag but not that much,but then there's the worse part,bandits. Guys who camp and kill others on sight,although in the game,it's very punishable. Normally it's uncommon for such things to happen,but then if you're in a clan,it could get worse. Some clans play for the PvP usually,and there are plenty of them,unfortunately. I'm not that type of person,there are also other clans who are neutral or are trying to fight against the KoS'ing regularly. Here,pro's usually are the ones who know how this game works,people like me that played this game when it was in Russian. The bugs and lag were very problematic before,but I asure you,this new version will have it sorted,if only people would put up a bit more patience with this game like I did,then they might discover how fun it actually is. I put up with this game for quite alot,alot more than 26.5" hours :P . Probably more than 500+ in the non-steam version. That's all."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just wanted to write a quick review since I returned to play on the new PvE server after a several year break

The game is still incredibly challenging with very little hand holding...if you're wanting to be told what, how and who every step of the way this game definitely isn't for you. The mutants you fight are extremely aggressive and hard hitting...ie. you won't be running thru a small pack of mutant dogs and live to see the other side. The game is centered around exploring large maps with danger constantly at your elbow with minimal resources and living to tell the tales

I've been playing about a week and close to hitting lvl 11, it's been a blast but I'm an old-school player that enjoys a real challenge in the games I play. This game is NOT easy-mode, if you try to Rambo it you'll get chewed up and spit out.

The graphics are pretty good for an open world game, certainly not the best but still decent. Even though its in Beta with many things needing more polish it's still very playable.

One thing i recommend is to do the tutorial, it will give you more ammo right away...which you're going to need.

TLDR Very fun game if you're looking for an open world survival shooter that's a real challenge, fighting mutants of all sorts and like to explore...if you want an easy-mode game [like most games are] then this isnt for you.

Seemed promising, but after only a few minutes you realize that its absolute trash.

Why the game is ♥♥♥♥
-You can´t aim down sights and have to use some ♥♥♥♥ inaccurate crosshair
-The sounds are at best awful when they are not missing. For example when you reload the AK-47 it makes no sound at all
-Combat is ♥♥♥♥ as the enemies do not move smoothly at all but warp around
-Interacting with your equipment is ♥♥♥♥. You have to put a magazine manually on your AK-47, but you can only put it on when the gun is in your inventory

Pros

reviewText:
Small edit at the end

The obvious comparisson should be Stalker but that would be unfair. SZone is something between a FPS and MMO and doesn't do any of it particularly good.

The graphics are not even on par with Stalker-COP which is like ancient by this time. No animations for reloading, swapping weapons or aiming, instead you get a progress bar. NPCs have different skins but little in terms of animations. All lined next to each other is convenient but doesn't build any atmosphere. Buildings have loads of texture seams and projection errors which tells me not even the 3D artists gave a ♥♥♥♥.
Lag is a problem. The second enemy I encountered was already jerking around. This also makes menus unresponsive at times. I actually dropped my starting AK while dragging it into my hotbar because of that.
The quests will give you hints instead of a clearly visible objective on the map (I like). It forces some exploration and research but the writing isn't engaging at all. Maybe they tried but again they failed.
The atmosphere is not existant. It's like riding a spooky ride at an amusement park with every animatronic shut down and the lights turned on. Absolutely no sign of the mysterious and dangerous Zone except some sub-par fog effect.

Very interesting was the note in my inventory: Not longer used in game". Turned out I could have exchanged it for some basic starter gear previously. This no longer works and all the game does is tell you "no resources" when you try. Why is the item still there? Why is the exchange option still there? Why is there NO CLEAR indication why it doesn't work? Why do I have to spend more time figuring out if something is a bug or a feature than figuring out what is happening in the game world?

In 24 minutes I obviously didn't make it past the starting zone
date: but why would I want to? There is nothing in the starting zone I'd consider even remotely polished. If they don't put effort in ensuring a decent first impression

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those games with great ideas but with a dev team that is either to small or not competent enough to deliver.
The lag spikes, user unfriendly interface and annoyingly fast enemies kill the game for me.

With annoyingly fast enemies I mean the mobs charge you at an impossible speed and due to the lag that's often there you won't kill anything without getting hit yourself.
Selfhealing is slow and healing items are expensive.

Mission pointers, and you'll need those in this game to safe yourself from very frustrating objects searching, seem to be broken for about 50% of the missions. Not fun.

Someone wrote about patience for this game and how much it has improved since pre-steam.
Yes, the game has been improved but translations and textures won't save this game, it needs a working system.
At the moment, the game is work. Searching your ♥♥♥ of for unclear (still choppy translations) mission objectives and trying to stay alive against hordes of mobs which can swarm you on a whim.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello fellow gamers,

The game looked good in the beginning although the shooting and moving was very laggy. When you kill a rat 10 meters away for example it would die 2 seconds later, feels odd. I played it for about 5 hours and coped with the imperfections.

Plus and cons :

Has a big open world with many buildings to enter although further along the way many buildings interiors were shut     ( like flats). I like the survival to be as real as can be. Enter all buildings find dirty rats and vreepers everywehere whatever.

Mobs re popping is in some places immediate which ( with aggressive mobs) leads often to death after clearing a spot.

Weapons sounds are off, reminds me of the pop guns back in my childhood.

Stats, detoriation of gear, levelling and crafting seem solid though. Maps are looking good, mobs are ok for an MMO style game.

Conclusion :

This is the sort of game we post apocalyptic game likers would like to have, fix the lagg ( Shoot lagg) and spawning , also quests are too many and too many daily like based which is neverending and chaotic to many players ( including me). Also the quests aren't always very clear on what to do as are the NPC quest givers ( from players). How many times i clicked a player thinking this was a NPC to get the message  would you like to trade with ......". All in all great potential
date: and free to try ;). I will check back later to see if they made progress."

If you have high expectations then expect to be disappointed, this is a F2P and you get exactly what you paid for. This is not a STALKER clone, and you are wasting your time if you think it is. But if you have a group of friends who know how to have a good time then this game is hard to beat in terms of entertainment value.

Overall would rate 5 kebab out of 5.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

its a good thing this game doesent have the stalker name in the title as that would be very insulting, the stalker game series are some of the best games i have played, though room for improvement exists and the story should have been longer. still it tries to play on our feelings for the stalker games by implying its a stalker game(you are a stalker running around in the zone in the game after all).

the game was all russian up to a couple of years ago and since then its been poorly translated into english but not enough for decent gameplay, npc names on the map are still in russian so if the quest marker dont point to them directly it can be a pain to find the right person. not having left the lubech station zone yet my knowledge is limited, but as that is the zone you will get to know the game in its the most important one so. the map is tiny, im not sure its bigger than the zones in the stalker games even. however it feels cramped with as much as 20ppl running around scavenging, stripping anomalies of artifacts and hunting animals, the later being potentially most annoying with ninja looters swooping in to loot your kills.

there are only a handful of anomalies to get artifacts from, and the few loot spots that exists are circled by a ton of people constantly and loot dont spawn that often, animals however respawn incredibly fast, you can clean out an area and just as you are running through it they spawn on top of you.

compared to what you earn from hunting animals and scavenging loot ammo, maintenance and eventually the replacement of worn out equipment is expensive.

skills.... well you get the basic skills pretty fast and consistently with level ups, but as soon as you choose a profession.. skills costs like 46k exp for one spec point, if your profession makes you proficient in a skill it costs 50% and if you suck at a skill it costs 150%, but in turn you need 10 up to even 300 spec points just to earn a skill. and killing mobs dont net much experience, you get a bit more if the mob drops loot and you take it, daily quests become boring after day 2 as most mmo players already know, and they dont net much exp either, there are lots of repeatable quests but they are just an alternative to simply selling the loot you get from grinding mobs. in the lubech station there is no community, there is no reason to team up with other players, a game this small needs instanced zones and that it dont have as far as i know, im guessing the later areas requires teamwork to properly gain access to but like i said, lubech is where you start to play the game(there is a zone before that but its merely a tutorial) and thus its supposed to convince players to continue playing, but it fails quite remarkably at it.

another thing, doing certain quests will reward" you with rusty versions of weapons you can get
recommended: you can waste storage space on them so you dont have them weighing you down but you cant get rid of them.\n\nspeaking of weight
hoursPlayed: what you wear and use weighs a ton

reviewText:
I used to like this game, I played it a lot and got pretty far considering I had no help from the very start.  Now however It's just become a complete waste of time and source of frustration.

The game is now split between PvE and PvP.  You can only choose one mode (before these modes we're combined - which was much better in my opinion).

You mostly get shot from behind by clan players with much more powerful guns than you have, in much more powerful suits and armours - there is no real fighting back if you are on your own.  You have to join a clan, which is hard considering they have something against English speaking people and prefer shooting you first and shoot you again if you get up or come back.

The biggest problem with the game isn't that though. I'ts the boars...  They are very fast, very strong and always seem to attack in hoardes.  They also like attacking you from behind like the clans do.  They obviously adopted that style from pigs.  It's happened many times where you are just mobbed by a whole bunch of boars and the more you try and kill or clear them from the area - the more you keep dying, waiting to get up" only to be killed from the newly spawned hoard of boars.  You just can't win in this game
date: because the boars are weak mutants.  The stronger stuff is even more impossible to deal with.\n\nI play games to have fun and enjoy myself.  This game has been nothing but a frustrating grind that I was willing see through
recommended: but the changes made it even harder now where I don't see any point in trying to do any of it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review


Number one I am not an uber pvp master.  But I have played allot of games over many years and never felt I had to vent about any other game as strongly before I entered the S Zone.
I usually believe that most of the sniveling and whining about balance and cheating in pvp games are usually caused by younger people used to getting trophies for participation, the same ones who have  RTFM/L2P issues,  or who don't want to put in any effort in order to get the cool stuff.  And effort is a big thing in this game,  nothing comes from the zone without a struggle.  The one thing I first got hooked on was having to figure it all out myself,  from navigating a largly unmarked map to what the NPC's words really meant before they were translated to english. It was really fun,  I have always  enjoyed a challenging game.

About RTFM, forget about it. The manual is composed largly of myth,  like the zone itself. Even the devs themselves reach mythic proportions in S Zone,  some say that they even play on the PVP server,  racking up extraordinary kill ratios while observing and assuring balance. I cannot say myself that cheating or the devs padding stats does exist in this game, and would like to believe otherwise. But whether it does or not,  the PVP aspect is broken to the point me losing interest fast.

I particularly find it annoying that my rifle (cost $4.00 for 30 days) can dispatch charging boar with ease from 50-100 meters,  but trying to hit certain other  players  at half that range results in 25% hits or less.  Even the damage difference is painfully confusing,  I can hit an enemy with 6-8 times fairly regular with 7.62X51,  sometimes even up to 10 making the mark,  and in turn be killed by 4 rounds from same enemy. WTF?  Granted I am probably more easy to kill than most due to the fact that every weapon I have used seems to have a substantial  accuracy penalty when not stationary and/or in crouch,  as well as my reluctance to flit around like some sort of harlequin ninja doing a twitchy representation of Swan Lake.  While I am on the subject of ninja ballerinas,  they also seem to be able to hit me unerringly while running,  jumping,  doing pirouettes,  sometimes causing their bullets to bend around corners.  The stuff of legends indeed. FPS games where an advantage,  as opposed to a penalty,  is given to those who spam the space bar seem rather dated and silly,  to me anyway.

Now granted,  I am only lvl 18 as opposed to the cap of 30,  and no doubt several million experience points allocated to armor,  weapon, health/stamina recovery etc behind most players. But come on,  give a guy a break once in awhile,  I mean three 7.62 nato to the head should at least slow a man down one would think,  no matter what helmet he has on.  At least blur his vision a bit.

The kill ratio of some of these oober" players is the stuff of legend.  Maybe it is because they have spent too much time in the zone
date: allocating mass quantities of exp to their stats
hoursPlayed: using gold weapons and armor

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've voted 'Yes' to recommend this game in the hope that it continues development and gets significantly better, but it really should not have been released in this state, even as an 'early access' title.

It's pre-alpha at best, and the large number of negative reviews no doubt result from that.

I'd LOVE to see a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. clone with co-op multiplayer (actually, I'd prefer to see the original series modded for co-op, but that won't ever happen).

This definitely has the setting of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, but it's no where near the standard yet.

It's broken, incomplete and unplayable at this time.

Wait a few months and it should be a lot better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThough there are a lot of good things about the game (the shooting mechanics are enjoyable, for instance), there are enough things wrong with the game that it's hard to imagine it being popular in the near future. There's no quick fix or simple tweak here; it needs a substantial overhaul. The content comes at you so fast that it can be overwhelming and there's very little information available on the game in English. It took me several hours just to figure out how you get more ammo or how to sell my loot. (btw DEVS, an open auction house in the starter area could really help with the new player experience). There are a lot of different sandbox-type activities (metal detectors for mining, animal skinning, artifact" treasure hunting

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis feels like a late 90s game that was given a modest graphics update and translated into Russian.  Using the menus is a chore. reviewText:
Early Access Review

You find yourself crouching behind a tree, trying to see what's on the other side without being seen yourself.
You finally muster the courage to emerge from your hiding place to take a shot at the mutant standing 5 yards away. Suddenly you find yourself squinting at the screen. What's that thing on the ground off to the left?  Is that what you think it is?

YES. IT'S AN ARTIFACT. Change of plans. The value of that Artifact dwarfs the value of some mere mutant's pelt.
You holster your weapon and equip your Magnetic Grip Device.  You toss a rock in the general direction of the Artifact to check for deadly anomalies. You'd been fooled before and this time you know the drill. No unusual sounds or lights emerging from the ground where the rock was thrown. All clear.

By this time the mutant has wandered away to haunt some other sector of wasteland, uninterested in your rock-throwing antics. You're free to go collect your bounty in peace.
You sprint towards your newly found treasure, not because speed is necessary at the moment, but simply because you've understandably acquired a sort of paranoia that only surviving in a post-apocalyptic world can produce. You know running isn't the safest move right now, but you get the feeling that if you don't hurry and grab your Artifact, you'll somehow lose your chance.

BIG mistake.

You find yourself in a strange orange cloud of dust. Your legs don't seem to work correctly anymore. You double over in pain, your lungs full of what feels like cement... living cement.

It is then that you remember: You never equipped your Air Filtration Mask. You knew that going to Vesuvius meant an inevitable run-in with air-born toxins, but the only PPE mask you had at the time was so dumb looking! No one would talk to a nooby looking player wearing that thing! Alas, your pride has finally allied with the reaper. The first effects of Sporosis have set in, and it's second deadly stage is closing in fast.

With the Artifact only a few feet away, you know that there's a good chance you can at least pick up your prize before surrendering completely to Sporosis, or anything that happens to take advantage of your weakened state. You know that upon dying, it will be up to The Fates to decide weather or not you will be allowed to keep your valued Artifact. The Fates can be cruel, but it's worth the gamble.

Stumbling and wheezing in agony, you soldier on towards your goal. Nothing else matters now; not the quest to find Vlad's son, not that new assault rifle you've been saving Ruples to buy, not the mysterious disappearance of those helicopters. This is all that matters: You must, nay, you WILL acquire your intended target.

You're close now. So close you can make out the beautiful patterns and strange designs forged on the Artifact's multifaceted surface. Forged by what, you do not know. By some force of nature, some unearthly power, some will of pure evil, or will of pure good? Does it matter?

Out of the corner of your eye you see leaves and other forest debris pick themselves up as if of their own volition. They twirl and spin, faster and faster. Soon you find yourself no longer looking upon a graceful ballet of nature, but instead you find yourself gazing at a terrifying Vortex anomaly. It moves in unnatural patterns as if pacing, hunting it's prey. To your dismay it has decided to move in your direction.

A few more steps and you will have the coveted Artifact in your hands.
The pain hits you again. Not now. Why now? Your chest heaving, your lungs struggling to take in the next breath, you double over again. Movement is now nearly impossible for you, and moving faster than a Vortex anomaly is out of the question. The swirling mass of radioactivity intercepts your movement towards the Artifact with ease, and you feel yourself being pulled towards it's center. You are thrust skyward and for a moment you get the feeling that it's safer up here than on the ground. Your false sense of security is short-lived, however.

After being carried several yards away from your flight's genesis, you are hurled to the ground with what feels like an unfair amount of gravity assisting your trajectory. You hear as much as feel the crunch of bones being devastated by the force of your landing.

You are only allowed a few milliseconds of time lying on the ground before feeling an intense heat coming from underneath you. You've been thrown into a fire anomaly. The air around you seems to explode and you find yourself engulfed in hellish flame. Barely holding on to sanity, acting purely on animal instinct you roll to one side to escape the inferno.

Everything is pure white. A rush of cold air brushes your skin. You feel like you're flying again. Not like the last time, but faster. You feel as if your body is hurtling through time and space. You know this feeling; you've felt it many times before: A teleportation anomaly.

The rush is gone. The warmth of Vesuvius's volcanic region is back. The pure white is gone. The blood red sky of this time and this space is back, and with it the pain. Though discombobulated and mangled by the events of the last few moments, you manage lift your head from the ground and get your bearings. That's when you see it. The most beautiful thing you've ever seen. THE ARTIFACT! The teleportation anomaly brought you right back to being practically on top of the Artifact. With your last ounce of energy, ignoring the pain, you rise to your feet. It's time to claim your well deserved reward.

[*CRACK*]

You hear the unmistakable sound of an silenced sniper rifle. You don't have much time to interpret it's meaning though, because to recall such things requires a fully intact brain and a fully intact skull to protect said brain.

You've had your head blown off by YOLOsweg69TBAG

10/10 would try again.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Okay, let's me be honest about this: I was one of the people that fought to get this game into Steam in the first place. I was hyped about this game for a long time because I'm a huge fan of STALKER and figured this game could scratch that itch.

And it did.

The issues comes from the continued scratching of said itch, which this game cannot accomplish. The initial joy of entering a STALKER-like world is quickly removed as you realize how unpolished the game is. Normally this COULD be forgivable but in the case of sZone Online that actually creates a serious issue: The game is so unpolished it feels unstable and makes playing the game a difficult chore. I watched as at times I was tearing through mutants and players alike while at other times I would be killed by a mutant that was stuck in the ground or constantly stuck in an anomally even after respawning OR you get missions that aren't translated from Russian and THEN find out the mission is broken in the first place, so there was never a point. For times like these you NEED older veteran players to give you a hand because they MIGHT have the items you need before bad coding removed said items, etc.

What killed it for me, however, was simply how dull it began to feel over time. The game doesn't really present any decent progression. When you get to the Camp (if you play you'll know where I'm talking about) there's really not major reason to keep going. At that point moving on feels more like a hinderence and a nuisance while staying only makes the whole experience stagnant. That word, right there, is what this game is: STAGNANT.

As a free game I would recommend it to scratch that STALKER itch, but really you're just going to have to wait for a better game to come along to give you some ointment for said itch.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wish I could leave a positive review for this game, I really do, but I just can't.
I played a long time (1000+ hours) on the old EU server before it was shut down and now it's just sad to see what the game has become. It used to be simple and fun but now everything is needlessly complex to the point where playing it almost feels like a chore that would have you grind and farm for 100 hours just to make one useless item and every change the devs make seem to be intentionally making the game as inconvenient as possible in order to get players to spend real money. It's not even just the best weapons and equipment now that cost gold, even basic systems and mechanics suffer too. A long time ago you could use medkits to revive fallen allies but now you can only do that with a special item for gold. To auto-trade in the marketplace also requires players to spend gold.
Weapon balancing is horrible, it has gone through several changes and each one is somehow worse than the last and a recent change to the armor system looks like someone just pressed randomise" on all the stats.
From what I've seen all 3 steam servers have very low player bases which makes it feel like a single player game except with tons of lag
date: speaking of which seems to be worse than ever despite my lower ping on these servers.\nIt also feels like this is a game that will never leave the early access beta stage as the devs will milk the player base until there isn't enough left to pay the server costs."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Recently tried this game with some friends. Didn't get off to a good start with character creation not showing the next button to continue without exiting the game and relaunching. Once in game it take 20mins for us to get into a group as the invites only seem to last for 10 seconds and after those 10 seconds are up you still cannot reinvite them as it says they've already been invited to the group this would be a great place for breif tutorial.

We managed to get our first quest/mission and carry on into the game but it does seem extremely laggy and very difficult to find ammunition or even enough money to purchase any ammo.

One thing that was somewhat amusing was the ability to throw rocks at rats and dogs with this eventually leading to our own humiliating deaths.

I appreciate that the game is still in Greenlight and I hope it does improve but as it currently stands I cannot in recommend this game.

reviewText:
Yea I know, I only played 2 hours total. Consider that not enough time spent if you so wish, and have fun trying this junk.

To start out with: the language barrier. When I played this game, every player I met was Russian. All the NPC's voice acting is in Russian. Literally did not run into another English player in my 2 hours. (except the friend who I brought along in the first place to try the game with me)
Then let's see next.. We've got the difficulty: alright, so in a survival game, difficulty is a good thing yea? In this case, no it isn't.. The stats and skills are not explained, you are left to test things and figure it out on your own. (Unless they have changed that aspect within the past 2 months) The reloading is very buggy and to obtain ammo you pretty much have to choose the uhh class" that can craft it.. All the enemies hit very hard

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy primary issue with this game is that some dialogue options and the background speech is in Russian. While I understand  this is an Alpha game, this alone makes is somewhat difficult to know what you are doing (unless you speak Russian). The graphics remind me of Fallen Earth in Beta. They aren't great, but not so poor that is resembles Minecraft. Play it for a while, but get used to the mapmarkers being in Russian (you can add your own in your preferred language). My review at this point is ~4/10, but I do see some potential for this game to be a 6-7/10 (tops). Since I have to decide whether to recommend the game or not to post this I will say that I am undecided.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Russian-English translations are god awful, the directions for quest suck almighty huge ♥♥♥♥, and the control format is so convoluted and totally unusable it’s ridiculous. Hell, some of the diologue options needed to advance the game are not acutally translated into English.

Despite reaching level 5 I was unable to initiate, much less understand, the following concepts (because the game doesn’t tell you how to do them at all, and there is no godamn intro for them – there aren’t even ♥♥♥♥ing instructions online):

1.	Craft
2.	Use the quick action bar
3.	Use the assault rifle, or any weapon besides the pistol
4.	Load the correct ammo I wanted (the ammo system is completly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ - I've never seen a worse system).
5.     Use the tools system

This game is glitchy as hell. Random items (not time limited items) would disappear. There was so much lag in the game that I’d shoot a rat and it would die five seconds later. The animations are terrible or nonexistent. The textures are terrible. I wouldn’t care about the textures, or modeling if there was at least some stylization, but that doesn’t exist!

No ♥♥♥♥ing wonder this game is free!

Also, despite asking in the politest manner possible, all other players refused to help me. And I’m not talking about giving me items. I’m talking the strait out even telling me basic instruction on how to craft and heal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

♥♥♥♥ the reviews, this is a pretty neat game. It's extremely similar to Stalker and that's a good thing for stalker fans. I'll keep this review short; to the people that wants a refund come on.. It's 99 cents. To a working person that's a really small amount lol.

Pros:
+Stalker MMO
+Great atmosphere
+Pretty populated
+ First and thirdperson mode
+Pretty great for an mmo (skills,classes etc)
+Easy to get into
+99 cents!

Cons:
-Pretty ugly
-The fps is unstable (DayZ-wise)
-The translationen is mediocre
-Not fully translated so some russian

All in all i would give this a 6. You should absolutley get this if your a stalker fan. Hell even if you're not it's only 99 cents.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[EDIT]

I can see that you guys updated the game! You guys added first person, games run smooth now at Ultra with 71 FPS. So you fixed performance. AWESOME! I just wish more people played this.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is my review before they updated and added first person and fixed performance ---

This game I like so far. I love the idea of it so much! It's like a RuneScape/World of Warcraft type of game but its based on modern times and has real weapons. Not all fantasy like.

Really, the only things I don't enjoy about this game is that stupid guy CONSTANTLY talking over the radio that speaks Russian so it's worse because I can't understand him. But seriously, make it so he does not talk NON-STOP. It's soo annoying. And the second thing I don't like, is the performance. It just sucks. My computer is good enough to run it ultra 60fps, but nope, this game I have to run at medium with 27-31 fps average. Third thing I hate about this game is that it is not first person. Not a big one, I can deal with it, but a game with guns, should be an option to go first person. Kinda got sad when I figured out I could not go first person. Other than that, everything is fine.

I really do see myself playing this game for HOURS and HOURS. But I am just going to wait for a few better updates to come out. I really hope you add first person, and add english audio. May take some time but I can wait! And make the guy stop talking CONSTANTLY.

I forgot something, you should also add mission markers on the mini map when you are doing a mission. When I do a mission/quest, I don't know where to go because there is no marker on the mini map. Other than those problems, if they fix them, this game could be an awesome game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played 22 hours the past 3-4 days, I am eager to see this in full english, once you get to the second town the game really does pick up with doing quests, search areas over and over many items in rail cards at stationfor example respawn new and different items for crafting weapons and ammo etc. the skill system is a bit awkward to get used to and even to understand, so fat i spent alot of my exp points (69k) into clothing skill to wear the first torn chaki and jacket you get from quests, only to find oout I still cant wear them, have not recieved ingame help from other english speaking players yet as to why.
Search everywhere, over and over so many people can get to it before you and the starting zones are packed with players. This is not a fast race to level up and be awesome and unkillable like most shooter games, seems like its designed is for prolonged game play with realistic learning you would see in real life as a survivor going thru this. You wont expect to be great as a normal person being thrown into an apocolyptic society and be a natural born killer over night, its gonna take time.
Overall, I can see this game being great and a huge success when its full translation is completed, as it is now its alot of fun, does need some english speaking moderaters who will be online to help us" get the hang of the game and answer questions until its updated fully!!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[edit] The title seems to have broken the terms of using Steam and has been taken off the store page.

It thankfully now launches after a hotfix. It is also free from their website but (could before hand) be bought on Steam for a special 100 ingame money.

Getting right in:

The title looks god awful no matter the settings, the FPS goes up and down like a hookers knickers this title needs to greatly improve these performance issues.

A plus and a good thing is, it can be played in 1st person (F4) to help with immersion, NPC quests however don't help to much immersion wise as tthey are guessing games not that they are all in Russian they just hold no real interest to whoever is reading them after the 5th time you've been looking for the right NPC.

Its like reading the same lines of text numerous times guessing/looking for the right NPC at the right time to trigger the right event, this chore increases the unhelpful likelihood off skip ahead important text. NPCs names are from what I've seen all in Russain which means you will more likely be checking every NPC to try and find out who the hell is who, hence the burnout above. A fix of giving them English names will help greatly somewhat with the above. Like invisible walls its plagued with completing linear collecting  tasks/quests that bores you to tears. I do hope that after the 1st town this game opens up. It could do with dumping the old tried stadard MMO stuff and replace it with more open-world survival.

The controls themseves i can't really fault and seem stantard stuff for a MMO. The community I have had little interaction with its hard to know if its toxic or not due to langauge. Althou the community do love to spam areana invites every two mins that got me killed twice. Specailly when you are on your way to collecting (x) number of mutant pubez as part of the quest/task you've been given. I'm sure all MMO's are just  the same game reskinned it like they don't have a orignal thought between them.

I'm keeping this title a thumbs down for now. Its just not the langauge barrers, the NPC interactions with yourself, the proforrmance issues. Its a title that has missed the boat a longtime ago, its been under delopment for years, looks older than even that. At this moment I can't see this becoming anything special, its a old game that has been given CPR due to current interest in surivial games. I would recommend any of the REAL S.T.A.L.K.E.R games over a average f2p MMO that simply plays homage too it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I only lasted around 40 mins or so playing this free ♥♥♥♥♥♥me.
It's clearly inspired from the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games.

When starting the game you will be prompted to choose a name for yourself, then choose two factions, Locals and Aliens. The locals are those that survived since the start of the zone's outbreak, while the aliens is a given name to those that come from outside the zone. It's stated each faction has several classes, though you don't actually get to pick them at the start. I presume that's later on.

The character creation isn't too bad, it has 25 head options, the rest are starting clothing, boots and pants, which are either 8 options to 5 options with boots and pants.

Overall the graphics aren't amazing, it feels like a game from 2006 or even before.
As said, the surroundings and theme feel alot like a stalker game. You'll have to be highly interested in stalker games aswell as being okay with playing a low graphiced game to enjoy this. It's not horrendious mind you. But it's no way near perfect.

Apparently the game started as russian only, but english has been added to the quests and dialog with npc's. There are just quite a few english typo's, aswell as a few laughable sentences that is no doubt poorly translated by someone who was a russian. For any grammar nazi, it is cringe-worthy, but hey, even Overkill made a few typo's in their payday 2 game.

The guns look slightly better than the character textures and you can switch between first and third person.
The enemies are quite various, but also rather low textured. Interestingly though, there are anomalies in the game, another element famous from the stalker series.

Once you leave the starting zone, you have a choice to go into a safe zone (a large town) but warned that if you leave it, you will be out in open pvp atmosphere. You also have a second choice, to go to the same town, but it is just pvp instantly, so there won't be a safe zone.

The game also has a store to buy ingame currency for real money, but the buyable stuff that requires this currency don't look impressive, more like retextured items that other vendors already sell ingame.

I only managed to play around 40 mins again, so I haven't covered all of the game, no doubt by far. But I wasn't impressed when I arrived to the town, and quickly decided to save my time on other games. Again, this free game is worth a try if you enjoy stalker/wasteland games, if not, you'll only be in it for a few minutes before deciding to uninstall like so many others.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

played this before it came to steam, when the server was in russia. My friends and i had more intense and funny expierences on this game then any other. The community was very tight and everyone knew everyone. The game is hard to get the hang of but when you learn to survive it becomes beyond fun. There are 3 zones we reached the 2nd was still hard to survive even after playing for around 90-100 hours, we aquired friends and enemies through-out our playthrough of the game as well.

The difficulty becames greater and greater where the best loot is, For example PPSH-41 is one of the most expensive in game items. We heard rumors of the ppsh farm and didnt believe them until we met the most hated man in the game Legion" The leader of the strongest PK clan in the game at the time
date: he agreed to lead us through a mine field
hoursPlayed:
insta-kill floor traps. it took us 30 minutes of following him while he protected us to get to the ppsh spawn and even then there was a low chance they were even there. After Legion showed us the way we began to charge money to be a guide for other players to get to the ppsh farm.


Horribly worded and awful grammar but this is just one example where we used an outside game idea into a business. Register that for a second We made a business in a survival game. People knew us from giving them guides where ever we went. We would get PM etc to help them all over the map. Sorry for the rant but the game is amazing give it a go"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It has a lot of potential, but I think I'll wait until after early access.

I like how the game doesn't hold your hand, which some people on here consider a negative. More games need this, but I think what sZone's main problem in this regard was improper presentation. Within 5 minutes of playing, you already kind of feel like you're writing with your non-dominant hand. It just kind of throws you into this world without much explaination of what's going on. The game could do with a more gradual approach.

Overall, here's a short list of what I noticed during my 40 minutes or so of playtime.
- Bad combat response. There doesn't appear to be any animation or blood splatter when you hit an enemy
- Bad dialogue UI. The dialogue seems to scroll up instead of scrolling down, and the list of response choices are basically just buttons on a window.
- The performance is horrible in proportion to its graphics. The shaders are actually pretty decent, the textures for the environment aren't so bad, either. Other than that, the game looks like something from 2003 and runs at 25-30 FPS for me. I can usually achieve 40-60 FPS on graphically superior games.
- Very quiet. I can get behind games without voice acting, but the lack of ambient sound makes the game feel very uncanny.
- The interface could use some explaining

reviewText:
Hello everyone,

Szone is a different game, unlike most MMO's or Survival games out there, Szone has taken whats great about a MMO and whats great about a Survival game and they have put it together. If you die, you lose items in your inventory depending what you are carrying, any items equipt will not be dropped, this allows players to have a purpose when killing others, it is not your average tab target MMO where you die, run out, die again, repeat, no.. This mmorpg is about fighting or befriending who you want for whatever reason you want, the purpose can be to take their loot or mabye you have some unresolved conflict with them earlier? Mabye you want to be their friend but you decide you dont like them and want to part ways with their belongings?

What you do is only limited by your creativity, this game has a completely player driven economy, clans take bases which allows them to acquire rare devices such as land mines and then that clan has the power to decide who can and cant have these devices, this is what starts alliances and wars, clans will either decide they want to help the clan in control of the rare resources/devices so that they can get some too eventually or they will decide to wage war to take what they want.

The PVP combat can be compared to counterstrike, rust and dayz, there is bleeding, illness and medicine to heal like dayz but turn the wrong corner and you will die in a heartbeat from a fully automatic AK which will fire similar to counterstrike, the reason i say counterstrike is because the recoil and spray resembles counterstrike more than it does dayz or rust. The Political/RP aspect to PVP could be compared to Darkfall: Unholy Wars or Arche Age, you fight for bases / fortifications, you control the resources, the goal is to control the game.

Now when you start the game you will probably be put off by the mid 2000 style graphics or the unexplaining UI/controls   but if you can see past the early game difficulties, this will become a game almost any mmo/survival game enthusiast will enjoy and about those mid 2000 style graphics i mentioned, this game is going to go to the Unreal 4 Engine eventually, it has already been announced, the game is released but still has alot of plans for the future.

I could go on for ages about this game, i have not even scratched the surface about everything i would love to say about this game, all i will say is just try the game, see for yourself, give it a few hours, you wont regret it.

See you in the Zone,
Reno

Character name: RenoTheOne

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played this game for a while now, this game has huge pontential but there are just minor things which are a pain and just need to change to make it much better and a recommendation to the developers, to be fair it is an early access game but it has been updated frequently but they seem to be missing these specfic issues which would make the game much better and get more people to play sZone instead of putting them off to play other online games.

As it is this is what I give it 6/10- these issues below where addressed this would get 9/10 easy.


1) Bugs and Flaws

This game is some times buggy, lags and also character can get stuck on something or when going upstairs and in buildings in particlar when logging off and log in again to where I left off, this is an issue which many people playing this find and is frustrating since forces players to start again with new character and is a major put off, the developers need to iron this specfic issue out, may be concider changing the stairs akward angles, when going up lags on corners, could be causing this issue and as a suggestion for example Fall Out New Vegas, great game looks good outside as well as inside areas, most inside looks the same area(s) but they slightly changed some, no akward angles, going upstairs has metal stairs, each room is accessible plain and simple something like to be applied in sZone would be much better and easier for people to access inside of buildings better, as well as houses, camps just saying, just a slight ajustment.

2) Buying and selling

The trading sytem is decent but buying and selling is clunky and is a pain, when scrolling and dragging items, equipment etc. does not respond well and to do is frustrating, it would be better if you can just click right mouse on item then have a little menu with sell, buy, and then drag item into the bottom inventory of the doctor, dealer, gun merchant guys inventory bottom one not top etc, Conan unchained game is a good example of how it should be done, with the price for buying and selling on each item is on the side, would be much better and alot of newbies as well as experienced players would find this much easier note to developers.

3) Combat, Targeting sytem, Enviroment and A.I

Is good but the cross hair to target an enemy/ enemies looks dated, also cannot see yor full character legs feels like an old ps2 game, should see full.

The enemys just need polishing up make them look more scary and better variety of them e.g could have ghouls, zombies radiated, giant worms just saying and A.I of enemy each enemy behaves in a different way and using different tactics against you e.g pack of dogs work as a team to abush you, mutants come out of water, spit acid, use different attacks have strenghs and weaknesses, also enviromental hazards some which you can actually use to your advantage as a weapon, a trap against enemies etc therefore it effects how you play and think of each weapon and the enviroment you use for each situation after all it is a post apocalyptic MMORPG themed game but feels the opposite sometimes like an army game just shooting things and picking items off them, note to developers.

Also when you shoot a creature, mutant, rat etc it just feels like no survival at all and is dull, there should be a manual targeting sytem or semi auto what ever the player prefers, shooting a particlar part of the enemy(s) body, shoot leg enemy is stunned, head shot instant kill, or a stealth kill option when sneaking behind an enemy, also hiding, near boxes, and been able to use some of the enviroment to your advantage would also make sZone much better and exciting and feel more survial note to developers.

Also depending on weapons etc, rifles, pistols, also you should be able to modify and update weapons with parts like you can do in Fall Out New Vegas just saying also unique wepons and rewards for harder missions and in secret locations.

These issues above would make this game much better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok so i thought i would do a review about this game because there are many bad reviews out there.
First of all keep in mind this game is early access and free to play now.

Cons
-Bad character creation (doesnt include females or any kind of facial customization)
-Not that good chraphics
-You get weapons way too fast (you get an AK as an quest reward almost at the start of the game)

Pros
+Interesting world
+Lot of quests
+Easy to lern how to play now that they fully translated the game to english
+Interesting enemies

I think this game is quite good game for an early access free to play game it has some bugs and other minor things but its quite fun i recommend you to try it out
6/10
